text:
SPEAKER: So as I
said, today we're going to be talking about the
Modern Internet Explained.

So we'll talk a little
bit about the evolution of the internet over the
past several decades, what the internet is like today,
and some common misconceptions

about how people
behave on the internet. And, finally, if
we have a chance, we'll also discuss some
security and privacy challenges,

both what we're seeing
currently and what Zakir is expecting in the future.

So to talk through
the modern internet, we're joined by
Zakir Durumeric, who

is an Assistant Professor
of computer science here at Stanford. His research brings
a large scale empirical approach to the study
of internet security, trust

and safety. What that means,
in part, is that he builds systems to measure
complex network ecosystems,

and uses those perspectives
that he-- from those systems to understand real
world behavior,

uncover weaknesses
and attacks, and then architect and deploy
more resilient approaches and guide public policy.

So Zakir, welcome. Thank you so much
for joining us today. And maybe we can begin, if you
just could tell us a little bit

more about what your
research is and how you approach that research. ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Yeah,
thank you for having me.

And, folks, please
don't hesitate to leave questions online. There's so much that
we could talk about.

The internet is probably
one of the most vast topics we could try to fit into
one webinar, and always happy to dive into where
people's heads are at.

My name is Zakir Durumeric. I'm on the faculty in the
computer science department here. And most broadly speaking,
I study the internet.

And this really
spans all the way from understanding the plumbing
of the cryptographic standards

and how we securely communicate,
how do we protect email and web transactions online,
all the way up

to how do people spend
time on the internet, how do we protect against
sort of abuse online,

how do we look at where hate
and harassment occurs online and everything in between.

And that's of what makes this a
fun topic is we have everything

from the people aspects
on one end of it all the way down to cryptography
and high speed, high performance

systems and networking
on the other side. The other piece, though, that
makes the internet, I think,

really interesting
but also really tough to challenge is just
how distributed it is

and how complex it is. You have hundreds of thousands
of different networks, all run by different operators.

You have businesses
who are involved in the core of the internet,
folks like AT&T and Verizon.

You have different
governments who have different opinions on what
the internet should look like, what their citizens
should and should not

be able to view
online, how they should interact online, what companies
should be able to do online.

There's this innate political
nature of the internet. You have these security
and privacy concerns that

are tied into this as well. How do we provide people what
they want on the internet while also maintaining
their privacy

and security on a daily basis? Security is one of
those areas where there's an active adversary.

In a lot of other parts
of computer science, and we're trying
to build something that works faster or is more
performant or is more stable,

here, you actually
have folks globally who are trying to break
into these systems.

And in a lot of cases,
we don't necessarily have the legal
structure to stop that from happening internationally.

And so the only
solutions that we have are technical solutions
for protecting against these attacks.

And all of these things have
to work together in order to provide the
experience that everyone has on a daily basis
for much of our society

to continue to function
on a daily basis as more and more of the internet
is dependent on in our day

to day lives. SPEAKER: That was already a lot. And I hope we're-- I think we're going to get to
some of those different aspects.

So I want to-- maybe we'll
start with user behavior, get into governance and
business side of things. And I know you have an
interesting background there.

And then, finally, maybe we can
talk about the technical side and what you're
seeing technically in terms of the infrastructure
supporting the internet.

But maybe before we
even jump into that, can we dig a little
bit deeper on how you research the internet.

I mean, for a system
that is so distributed, that is so complex-- I mean, it's one of the
great world systems, I guess,

in some sense-- how do you even go about
studying it empirically? ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Yeah, we have
to be really creative here

because there isn't like one
central place where we can go and we can collect data and
we can make sense of things.

What you have is this giant
interconnected network, it just really depends on
the question you want to ask.

In a lot of cases what
we'll try to do is we'll try to build systems
that will go out and be

able to do large scale
measurements of what's happening in practice. And I think the big piece that
drives this is the internet

is far too
complicated and messy, and there are far too
many players for us to really be able to
model any aspect of it,

to have these theories
about how things work. For the most part, when
we come up with theories, they break down in practice
just because people

have different incentives. They don't necessarily
want-- what they want to have happen is not
necessarily perfect performance,

might be business driven or
sort of financially driven. And so what we do is we try to
go out and do these large scale

measurements. Sometimes this means working
with big providers, folks like Google or Cloudflare or
Akamai or Amazon, and saying.

Across all of the traffic
and all of the connections that come into you, what are
the patterns that you're seeing?

Can we come up with
these experiments and work with you to run one
of these experiments that doesn't hurt your
performance too much

but lets us tease out
these patterns of behavior? Sometimes it means in
going in actually crawling

massive parts of the
web, going and connecting to these websites. How do you build
these web crawlers

that can connect
to these websites, pull down content,
analyze it at this scale?

What are the mechanisms that
my group focuses on a lot is this notion of
internet scanning.

And the idea here is
going out and connecting to every internet connected
device, every router,

every server, every
cloud provider. And looking at in
these connections

to each one of these
devices, seeing what is the data that those
devices give back to us

and can we derive patterns by
the little bit of information that is sent back. And you might think, how much
data do these servers really

give you back that lets you
make sense of the internet? But at times you're able
to actually glean out

these patterns of behavior. And I think a really
good example of this recently that we've
been looking at is, how

does-- what does performance
on low Earth orbit satellite networks look like? Now, this was something that
in the past low Earth orbit,

like networks, are pretty new. Starlink was the first
player that brought this

to widespread consumers. And there's a lot
of folks now that

are getting access
to the internet through these low
Earth orbit satellites. And the problem is that how do
you go out and you measure this?

One option could
be you could try to buy a whole bunch of
these satellite dishes, you could try to get
people all over the world

to put up these satellite
dishes and tell you about their experience. And now you have
this problem of, how are we going to manage
this army of volunteers?

And how do we make sure that
the numbers that they get make sense? And what do they
get out of this?

Why do they want to help
us measure their satellite performance? Everyone knows globally
that we need to know this,

but what incentivizes
them as an individual to want to participate
in a study like this?

And what we found
was that we could see many of these actually
satellite endpoints out there on the internet.

And you can start
to do measurements that say how quickly
the packets go back and forth between Stanford
and those satellite endpoints.

And if you can do this
for a couple of endpoints, it's not that necessarily
that interesting but if you can do this for
thousands or tens of thousands

of these endpoints, you
can start to see patterns. You can start to see these are
regions where things are faster

or slower, these are places
where the connectivity seems to not match our theoretical
model of how these satellite

constellations work. And we can dig in and say,
why does this sometimes match this theoretical
model and sometimes not?

What is it about
how these satellites have been deployed, about
how traffic is routed, about the behavior of users
on these networks that

lead to these actual
performance characteristics? And this is one
example where we were able to make sense
of performance,

but there's a lot
of other places where we can do this
to understand security, to understand
misconfigurations to say, OK,

if we look at every
misconfigured web server, let's say, in the world, what's
the pattern that some of these

are configured and
some of these are not? Where are the places that people
patch for vulnerabilities faster and places where they're not?

We can go talk to
those people and say, hey, why didn't
you patch your web server like everyone else did?

And be able to tease apart
why certain things work and why certain things don't
work, and update our models

and come up with
better solutions to build better technologies,
to build better protocols that address these problems
we're able to identify

through these measurements. SPEAKER: That's
super interesting. You're making me nervous. Have I patched-- is everything
of mine patched to you?

So we already got a quick
question that maybe is worth asking right at the
outset is, so when

you're building these
models or their scanners, the topic that's at the
forefront of everyone's mind

is machine learning,
AI, neural networks. Are you starting to
integrate some of those? And what would that look
like into a scanner,

into something that's
probing for vulnerabilities at a internet wide approach? ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Yeah,
this is a great question.

And it is a question
that everyone's asking is like, what does
machine learning really mean for security.

And I generally have the
opinion that machine learning in a lot of ways can accelerate
different directions we're

trying to take research. So for one example, for the
measurements we're doing, we go out and we collect
all of these devices,

but there's this question
of where are these devices? Who owns them? What industry are they in?

Trying to make sense
of that data is hard. People don't say this
system belongs to utilities and this other one
belongs to manufacturing.

It's something you have to
tease out and be able to make sense of this data. And machine learning
is really good

there to take these
massive data sets and say, can they help us as researchers
make sense of this data?

To pull out these patterns
where we know what's in there and when you look at it, it's
obvious to you as a human,

is this a website
or is this a router? That's something that
you and I can look at and we can tell when we look
at the website of that device,

but there are so many
different types of routers, there are so many
different companies that make routers just in the US.

And then you think
globally, OK, you have all of these
different routers made by all of these
different manufacturers, and their interfaces are in all
of these different languages,

how do you make sense
of all that data? Is a place that we are turning
to machine learning to say, how do we label this data? How do we make sense of this?

How do we draw these
connections out? And that's really where
machine learning is, is going to, I
think, really help us

in the security space is
saying we have all of this data and we're trying to
find these patterns. Which of these connections come
from attackers versus our work

from home users? Which of these is
one of these users that is traveling this
week or is an attacker?

Even from a connection
from someone's home machine is that actually that
employee or is it someone who's attacked
and taken over that system

and is making malicious
connections from their computer? How do you distinguish
those things? And we live in a world today
where, for the most part,

security systems are able to
collect massive amounts of data, they're able to collect way
more data than anyone in a sock

or in a security organization
is able to make sense of. The other place we're using
it is to figure out not how

to only make sense of
everything we find, but how do you find everything? We used to think we knew
how to find everything,

and it turns out finding
everything on the internet is actually quite
hard where you have to think of the billions of
different names of websites that

are out there, you have
to look at IPv6, which has this massive search space. There are two to the
128 IP addresses.

This is more than sort of
atoms in the known universe sort of numbers. It's not something we can
ever measure all of it,

so where do we
even begin to look? And you can start
to derive patterns to say people put routers on
these addresses but not these,

or this network tends to use
this sort of addressing scheme, or in this network, something's
on this weird port that

isn't anywhere else but
is on that network seems to be a port that they use. And so also finding those
patterns tells us where to look.

And then once we find
things on the internet, it helps us to derive these
patterns from that data.

SPEAKER: That's
really interesting. Yeah, when you were
saying you were going to look at every
internet connected device,

the immediate
question was, well, how do you find every
internet connected device? And there you go,
it's hard to do.

It's hard. ZAKIR DURUMERIC:
Yeah, it's hard, yeah. And then they change, they move. None of this is static.

And this is things come blurry. If you look at, hey,
we're going to look over the internet over
the span of a week, well,

you're going to count
some things multiple times when they move around. You're going to miss
other things that are only up during nighttime
but not during the daytime.

And all of these real world
factors you have to address or you'll miss
countries worth of data

because the weekend
in that country is a weekday in this
other part of the world.

SPEAKER: That's interesting. Yeah, that's really interesting. We had one more quick
follow up question on this.

There was a very specific
one about what tools you're using to do
the satellite studies.

But maybe more broadly, do you
have examples of any tools? I know you've built some, can
you mention a few of these

or what you're
using to do these? Are these things
you're building? Are there tools that are
out there that people can use for this kind of research?

ZAKIR DURUMERIC: It's
a little bit of both. But my lab does maintain many
of the big internet measurement tools.

So we created a
scanner called "ZMap." We also have other scanners
like ZGrab and ZDNS that we use,

and are used across the industry
for doing these types of scans. ZMap is interesting
because this year,

there is another
research group that came out that said the
majority of all scans on the internet
actually come out

of ZMap, from the
open-source tools that we create and maintain. We also work with a
lot of other companies.

And we work with groups
like Censys and GreyNoise, folks who are
going off and doing these scans on a regular basis
or are deploying honeypots.

We work a lot of times with big
organizations like Cloudflare and Google, and
those folks who have their perspective on the world.

It really depends. A lot of the times, we're
developing tools and making them available to other researchers. We tend to dogfood those
and use them ourselves

to figure out where do they
work, where do they not work. And that's of
important to us, is you don't really know
how well a tool is going

to solve a problem until you're
the end-user who has to use it and has to bang your head
against the wall and say, we thought this question
would be easy to answer.

But now that we're
actually answering it, it turns out to be pretty tough. We have a new system we've been
working on for the last couple

of years called "Retina," which
lets us ask questions of massive

internet service providers
for all the traffic that goes through a network, to
ask questions like, how is cryptography
being deployed?

Where's cryptography broken? And that is a system that's
under active development,

is one that allows us to
make sense of network traffic and ask these security
questions of it.

SPEAKER: We're getting a lot
of really good questions. I want to hear a little bit
more about your research. So maybe we can just-- before
I jump into the next round

of audience questions, is just-- you did a study a
little while ago

on-- what is it-- a worldwide
view of the world wide web. So I guess, what I'd love
to hear a little bit.

And that was the study of
user behavior on the internet. So maybe just starting
with-- what do you think is the common perception of
user behavior on the internet?

What were some of
the surprising things that you found in that study? And maybe, again,
saying a little bit

about how you conducted that
study, because I think that's interesting and important to
understand why your answers

might have been different. ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Yes. This is one of those
studies where-- it's shocking that the study
hadn't been done before to us,

but this was a study
that for the first time, we looked at how do people
actually spend time on the web.

We all spend all of
this time on the web, but we actually had
never really measured,

like, where does time go? If you were to look at the whole
world, the time they spend in

like Chrome or Firefox, where
are the websites they spend on? How much of the internet
goes to the top-five websites

versus all of the others? And this is something we
just-- we had no idea.

We had no idea that 10% of
traffic go to the top website, or just 50% of time go
to the first website.

And this was a project we did,
in collaboration with Google, to say, essentially,
where does people--
where does time go on the web? So what was surprising--

it's hard to say because
I feel like we just had no idea going in. We had so little idea
of where does this go.

We oftentimes, I think-- on the networking side, think of
the world in terms of how much

packets, how many packets
go across the internet. And we know that the
vast majority of packets

belong to video. That was what we
knew going into this.

In terms of what-- I think we found that was
really interesting, is just how

different, like
the desktop world is versus the mobile world. And really, how much
of the desktop world

has moved to the
business-centric sorts of things? And how much of time people
spend on the internet

is really on phones
and is on mobile. And I think that
looking at-- there's

these entirely two different
types of traffic or user on the internet, depending on--
are they at work, or are they

at home? And now that we say this,
it's like, well, duh. Of course, they do.

But it was the first time we
really had this data that said, these are the types
of things people do at work versus at home.

And if you look at the
weekdays versus the weekends, if you look at time during the
day versus in the evenings,

these look different. And they look different
in some surprising ways. So I think one of the
things that's actually

really surprising
is that for the most part, the security of
the connections we see and of the email
sent and all of this

is more secure during
nights and weekends than it is during the weekday. And this seems
sort of backwards.

You would think that people
sending emails from work would be using more
up-to-date technologies, more

secure protocols. But it's actually the
actual pure flip of it. Security of the internet,
all the connections,

is worse during work hours
than it is during weekends. And a lot of this,
what this comes down to

is that you have big
providers like Gmail and Hotmail and Yahoo.

And these folks were actually
have really good security. But all the connections that
are made on the weekends

to these public services,
they're all running HTTPS. They're all using
modern mail protocols.

The people who are
oftentimes behind at deploying these new
technologies are businesses.

It's banks and
insurance companies, and all of these
other folks who say, we don't want to use some
of these cloud services.

We don't want to have
all of our email run through Google or Microsoft. We're going to run
our own servers.

And I think, a lot
of times, companies think they're going to do this
to improve their security. But what we see when we
zoom out is these activities

actually reduce their
security as a whole because folks like
Google and Microsoft are keeping their
servers up-to-date.

They're deploying
the newest protocols. They're involved
in those protocols. And in writing those--
and this starts

to get into these other
questions of governance and who is pushing
the internet ahead. And the new protocols
that are coming out

tend to be these big tech
companies, not the folks that people use during the
day when they're at work.

SPEAKER: That's
incredibly interesting. So again, just to summarize,
what I'm hearing is at night,

most people are using
it for personal things like entertainment
and personal email. And therefore they're going
through major providers

like a Netflix or
Microsoft or Google. And they're all going to have
the latest and the greatest in terms of security.

And on the other
hand, during the day, you have a lot of
these small businesses or medium-sized businesses,
or even large businesses

that are running their own
servers, their own email. And therefore they're
not necessarily

as secure as what you're seeing. ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Yep. SPEAKER: You alluded to it. But just to also maybe clarify
a bit more, what you're

seeing on phones is
you're seeing that as the go-to for-- or mobile
devices for entertainment,

if I remember. ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Yeah.
SPEAKER: Yeah, broadly speaking. And then desktops, probably
more business or other

similar activities. ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Exactly. Most of the traffic in
the evenings and weekends comes off of mobile devices now.

It's iPhones and tablets. It's home-connected
TVs, things like this,

not the traditional
desktop computers that we see in enterprise environments.

SPEAKER: That's
really interesting. And are there any-- in terms of those, how did
it update your thinking

about the internet? I mean, you've already
talked to that a little bit in terms of the security. But is there any other way that
that study updated your thinking

about user behavior
on the internet, or how you're approaching or
thinking about, say, security, for example? ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Yeah.

So one of the things that
really pushed us to look at

is oftentimes we
think of the internet as this big, global
homogeneous thing.

There's the internet. One of the things that was-- I think that the research
community, for a long time,

has looked at
these websites that were like the top-million
websites on the internet. It makes sense, like study
the most popular websites.

You have these lists that
you maintain, your research. You have to start somewhere. One of the things that
was really interesting

was how different
countries are in this. And this was the first
time we had the ability

to tease apart and say, what
does internet web behavior look like in different continents
and different countries?

And what's really interesting
is-- some countries use major global providers.

And they use these
American providers. And other folks are using
much more internally developed

systems. If you look at where does
traffic go in South Korea, it looks totally
different than where does

it look like in South Africa. And there's these
really interesting

country-specific phenomenon. You see different
strategies for security.

We see things operating
in different timelines. And this really brought
us to this new question

of understanding of like,
are the actual differences between countries and how
they use the internet?

How they're centralizing? And we have this, I think, broad
notion in the research community

that the internet is
becoming more centralized. And this is of a big theme that
there's a lot of talk about.

And actually, what
a lot of worry about is-- if all of the
internet traffic is going to a small number of
players, what does that mean?

The internet was
originally envisioned as being this fully
distributed network.

But what's interesting is
that there is regionalization that's happening. There is centralization
that is happening.

There are isolationist
tendencies in some places. But what's really interesting
is to tease these apart.

And this is now a new
active area of research that we're looking at, is
like, what does it really mean for the internet
to be centralized?

Because in some
cases, the providers could actually be
really small, but they could suck up all the
traffic in that one country.

In some other places,
people that we think of as being really
big, like Amazon EC2,

actually don't necessarily
have the same weight globally. They have a lot in each
of these countries,

but they don't necessarily
have massive amount of traffic in any one country. And so if you think about GCP
or Google Cloud and these folks,

and you think about these
big cloud providers, I think in the US, we
think of these as the folks forcing centralization.

And what we see
in some cases is, in fact, they don't
actually have much effect on centralization
when you actually

start to look at the
country granularity. SPEAKER: That's
incredibly interesting.

There's almost-- what's it
called-- like maybe a Simpson's paradox here, where Amazon
is the biggest provider,

but it's not the biggest
provider in any single region kind of thing. So that's incredibly
interesting.

As the next step, I want
to get into talking more about the business and the
government side of things. We're getting a lot of
questions around that.

Maybe one more thing while
we're on this kind of research

project, it seems like
a lot of your research does depend on scanning
or web crawling.

What are some of the ethical or
practical approaches to thinking through that kind of research?

And we're going to talk
about it at the end that you teach a class. And I believe one
of the projects

is to do some web analysis. And one of the big
things is you're really

going to someone's website. You've got to think about
the implications of that. So can you talk through, as
you're conducting this research,

how do you do that in a
responsible and ethical way? ZAKIR DURUMERIC:
Yeah, absolutely. And this is a big
question for us--

and there's many
different aspects of it. We're going from
connecting to all of these systems
on the internet.

How do we make sure we
don't harm any of them? We don't accidentally knock
over one of these systems.

And there's a lot of
work we do to test the scanners we're building
to ensure that they

don't harm any systems. We go to great lengths
to make sure it's really clear who is doing
the scanning and why,

what we're trying to do. We make it really easy for
people to opt out of these scans and say, hey, we don't want to
participate in this research.

How do you make it easy for
them to get in touch with us? Or just to even understand
what we're doing. And what we find
in a lot of times

is when people do
reach out to us, it's like, what are you doing? Why are you connecting to me?

And we explain what we're
doing and why we're doing it. And the types of
things we've been able to do in the past with that
data, people are OK with it.

However, we have to explain who
we are, why we're doing this, and what we're trying to do to
make the world better from it.

And I think part
of this is also-- how do we take these results and
make the internet actually safer

and more secure as a result? Not to simply stop and say,
we've done the measurement. You have these problems.

Let's move on to the next
question we want to answer. But we do a lot of
work with browsers

to say, OK, how do we
improve these protocols? We work with standards
groups to say, OK, we see these problems in
how they're being deployed.

How do we fix this in the next
revision of this protocol? We've done a lot
of work on how you do very widespread
notifications of vulnerability.

So we've done a lot of work
with CISA to say, OK, here are utilities that are
actually vulnerable.

And we're seeing attacks
against these types of systems. Here are the systems. Can you work with them
to fix themselves?

And actually say, how do we
get this information out? What do we need to
provide to people to help them be more secure.

So a lot of it is-- we
start with the measurement on the research side. But a lot of it is-- how do
you take this the full length?

And say, how do we
actually improve the security of these systems? How do we notify people about
the problems of their systems?

And for the most part,
this is well-received, for us to reach out and say,
we're not selling you anything. We're not trying to
tell you anything.

There's this problem. Here's why we think
you need to solve it. And so here are some
instructions for doing this.

And we've done a lot of work
on-- how do you phrase that? How do you make that
communication effective?

How do you communicate that
you're not an attacker? Because we go through all
this phishing training. We go through all these
messages that say,

be skeptical of any
email you ever receive. It's probably an attacker. And the reality is it
probably is an attacker.

So why is it that you should
follow these instructions? And this is, again,
why relationships

with folks like the EPA
and the CISA with the FBI are so important--
is for helping

to disseminate this
information, actually get these systems
secured in practice.

SPEAKER: I think is
a nice segue maybe to thinking about another-- so we talked a little
bit about user behavior.

And again, we could
talk about it, I'm sure, for another 10 hours. But thinking about
the governance

and the business side of things. I wanted to
transition into that. And maybe we could start by,
if you could share a little bit

more about your
background, because I think one of the things
that's interesting is you had some
experience on the business

side of the internet. Or it seems like that might
have spurred or inspired some of your research or your
thoughts about the approach

to studying the internet. So can you talk a
little bit about that? ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Absolutely. So part of this course--

the modern internet that
I started really came out of the fact that-- I had started a
security company,

and we actually had to go out. We had to buy servers and
put them on the internet. And we had to peer
with other ISPs

at internet exchange points. So we to figure out where
should we deploy these servers. And who do we buy
IP addresses from?

And how do you buy internet? How do you choose if
you have ISP A and ISP B that you can buy internet from?

What are you
supposed to negotiate in that contract for internet? And there's this whole complex
ecosystem on the backend.

And we don't think
about this as consumers. Usually, we can
only buy internet from Comcast or Mediacom,
or one of these providers

that are homes. And so we don't
think about this. But the underside
of this is there's this whole ecosystem of
different internet service

providers. And they have strengths. And they have weaknesses. They have geographic
areas that they have more

connectivity in than others. And you have to think about
these questions of-- we send packets from this point
or from this other point.

Which of them is more likely
to get to the destination? Which of these are likely
to get there faster?

And what I realized is
there's this whole part of the internet we don't
talk about in networking courses, where we talk about--

here's what's been standardized. We talk about
protocols like BGP,

and we say packets
go the shortest path across the internet.

In reality, that's not true. The reality is they
go across the cheapest path of the internet, not the
shortest path of the internet,

because the core of the internet
is not a public service. It is run by large corporations.

You have what we call
these tier-1 providers, and these are folks like Verizon
and AT&T and NTT and GTT.

And they are businesses. And they think about
these questions that say, if we send the packet on this
path versus this other path,

which is cheaper? At this time of day,
where is their traffic? How should we
route traffic so we

can minimize the amount
of infrastructure we have to purchase? And at the scale that these
companies are operating,

these can have massive financial
impacts of how you move packets around on your network.

Just even the
question of how fast you can make the decision
of where to send that packet can have massive impacts.

You see companies
like Google and Meta actually laying their
own submarine cable now.

And these are massive billions
of dollars of investments to run cables between
continents so that they

have control over these-- how their packets flow. And all of this means that
shortest path is really not

how things happen. But we have to talk about that. We oftentimes don't. We start talking
about the algorithms.

We talk about what
is in the standards. And we say, yeah, companies
can do something different

if they want to,
but we don't talk about how they do in practice. And I think, going
out and actually having to peer onto the internet
and having to do these things

and have to run
these calculations and having to redline
these contracts for what do I want in the SLA for
my packets on the internet

made me see there's actually
a whole bunch of other content to talk about. And the internet has shifted.

We used to think
about the internet as being this very
hierarchical thing. All of us were the edge of it.

You had all of these small
regional ISPs and all of those would connect to the
bigger ISPs, someone

who covered a couple of states. And those sort of
mid-sized ISPs would all connect to the core
of the internet,

the backbone of the internet,
the AT&T and the Verizons. And they would take our
traffic internationally.

They would take it across
the continental US. And a lot of that's changed.

We have folks like
Comcast now who will say to Netflix,
why don't you pay us?

You're the one who wants to
send your video to our users. Our users are paying you. Why should we pay
you for you to charge

our users to watch your video? And you can make the argument
like who's right or wrong.

But the reality is-- this is now a contractual issue
between Comcast and Netflix.

And Netflix is so
big that this whole-- everyone is small, and
the edge goes away.

There's so much traffic that
goes to Netflix or to Amazon or to Cloudflare, that this
whole pretty hierarchical thing

has really crumbled. And most of this traffic, if
you're sending from point A to point B, might not go
through the core of the internet

anymore. But we like to teach it. We like to say,
all this internet goes to the core,
starts on the edge,

and it traverses from smaller
to bigger, back down to smaller. But the reality
is-- it might not.

It might just go from
Comcast to Netflix. It might never leave
Comcast because Netflix has shipped physical
server equipment to Comcast

in order for that packet
to not go on the internet. And it is cheaper for them
to buy servers and send

them to Comcast to
put in their network than it is to keep
sending these packets.

And all of these
things are the types of things you start to
realize when you actually have to look at-- where do the packets go?

And then, how do I change
where they're going to meet my own business needs?

SPEAKER: There's a
ton to unpack there. And I want to come back to

think it's important.

And again, coming back to
that philosophy or that experience that led to you
realizing how important-- this

is something that's just not
spoken of enough in Computer Science departments.

I guess my follow-up
question here, which is-- and I don't have it

you were talking

about this hierarchical model. I grew up in the Bay Area in
the '90s, so I have this very technolibertarian vision
of the internet as--

the classic one is the
cathedral and the bazaar. This is the bazaar. That's just this
marketplace, which

actually is similar to
what you're describing. And what's the other
one is rough consensus--

run code and rough consensus-- those aphorisms that
just to me seem still

define the internet in my
mind, I guess, in some sense. And you're saying it's changed,
like the nature of the internet

is just fundamentally-- it's almost sociologically
or business side changing.

So I was hoping you could talk
a little bit more about that and also talk a little bit
more about the governance

or the political side
of it, and how you're seeing that influence it. So you touched on
that earlier when you said you're seeing
real country level

or regional differences
in internet usage and approaches to security. Could you come back to
that and talk a little bit

how you're seeing if you've
laid this picture of maybe the business side of things
and how that's changing it?

How are the politics
coming in and changing the nature of the internet? Sorry, it took me a while
to get to that question.

ZAKIR DURUMERIC: No. It's complicated for sure. I mean, I think
when we all began,

we did have this
technolibertarian view. Everyone in the internet will
connect to everyone else,

and this will be
this pure notion. And a lot of that
does still exist.

I mean, for the most part, the
internet still is very open. We do still have big standards
groups like the IETF,

where people come together,
and we decide where to go. But you also have a
lot of heavyweights

on the technical side now. You have groups like
Google and Facebook, who have really vested
interests in the performance

notions of this. You have big manufacturers,
like Cisco and Juniper, who also have their business
that they're trying to sell,

and a lot of things, like
some of these new protocols like QUIC. So QUIC is a protocol
that replaces

TLS in some situations
with something that was developed
by Google in Chrome,

and then was deployed by
several big websites like Google and Facebook and others. And a massive amount
of the internet traffic

that people spend
on a daily basis start going over quick
simply because Google Chrome

implemented it. And several big
companies implemented it. And it wasn't a protocol
that was ever ratified.

It was just a protocol
that these folks decided-- this is going to give
us better performance. This is going to allow us
to get content in front

of people's eyeballs faster. And we have enough
internal testing to say, we're going to deploy
this to the world.

And now later on, the standards
community has caught up. They've come and they've said,
OK, this was interesting.

This worked. Let's take this, and
let's standardize it. And now, QUIC is
used everywhere.

But it didn't start
in the standards body. It started because Google and
Facebook and a couple of others said, we're doing this.

And the world caught up with it. You also have other policy
areas that aren't necessarily

run by these standards group
but are just run by browsers. So a big example here is-- every
time you connect to a website,

that website
essentially hands you what we call a
certificate that says, I really am
Bankofamerica.com And you

can trust that no one
in this coffee shop has intercepted this
connection and is

trying to steal your
username and password. I am the real Bankofamerica.com. And the way this works is
we have what are called

"certificate authorities," or
these big companies that we trust to vouch for the
identity of websites. So essentially,
someone like DigiCert,

which is one of these
CAs, says, this really is Bankofamerica.com
We have verified it. And Google, your
browser, Chrome says,

we trust that DigiCert
does this due diligence. The reality is the
browsers are the ones who

decide who you trust. This isn't something that
is figured out by the UN

or by Congress or anyone. The browsers say,
here's who we trust.

And this is actually
a good thing because they actually
have the ability to make these nuanced
technical decisions of who is

acting properly and who is not. But it's also a lot
of power to decide who you're going to trust.

And we've seen countries
come out and say, well, why should we trust Google? This US-based company
decide which websites

you're allowed to connect to. Why isn't this something
that our government controls.

Why is it something that we
want to have a certificate authority in our
country that operates under our laws and legislation,
not under US or EU law.

And this becomes this
question of, well, how is this going to play out
between the browsers, these tech companies, and governments?

And this is something
that comes up a lot, is you have governments,
and you have the internet, which is this
international entity that's

managed by a lot of
different companies. And how should legislation
and regulation work?

And the internet, for
the most part, I think, is becoming more balkanized
as time goes on, as there's

more geopolitical conflict. People are saying, do
we want other countries to have access to this content?

We've seen countries
come out and say, look, we don't want these AI
companies scraping this content. We've seen China put up this
great firewall of content

to censor which content comes
over their national border. We are starting to see this
in many different countries.

And the internet's not as open
and as free as it once was. And it's something that we're
really only figuring out

through large-scale
internet measurements. What sites are accessible
from some countries that are not accessible from others?

When the Russia-Ukrainian
war broke out, what did this mean in
terms of how traffic was routed in Eastern Europe?

And all of this conflict does
change this internet substrate. And it's something that is
changing on a continuous basis

as countries are reacting. And it's happening everywhere. But it's changing this
dynamic from being

this once very free and open
internet to something where

a lot-- I think of this community are
trying to figure out how do we work with governments. In the US, we look
at the ban on TikTok.

I think this is another
example of this. We decided that we don't want
content essentially controlled

by another country to
be used in an app here. Well, then, OK.

Which countries are
we OK having run apps? Which ones are we not? There's all of these
questions that I

think the community
is grappling with, and there aren't really
clear answers to any of them right now. It's something that is
very much in motion.

And even within the US, there's
a lot of disagreement right now about what is misinformation
and propaganda versus what

are differing
viewpoints on an issue. And this is something
that is very gray. There's very little black
and white in these types

of questions that are
being grappled with now. SPEAKER: That's great. Maybe we could build on that.

We've gotten a couple questions. There are obviously
a lot of things around that topic of content, of
internet content specifically.

Is it good for you? I mean, I just saw another one. Instagram is bad--
lowers kid's self-esteem.

Or Facebook, actually,
is good for self-esteem. So have you done some
research around that? And what have been
your approaches

to thinking about either
health or not security per se, but you might call
trolling or internet abuses

or misinformation? So what are some of the
information-- what have you looked at? And where do you see as the
state of the art of research

in trying to even
understand those phenomena? ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Yeah. No, my group has. And we've really looked at both
the hate and harassment side,

and then some of the
propaganda and disinformation side of the internet.

Hate and harassment
is a major problem. This is something that affects
a huge portion of users online.

And it has real-world
detrimental effect on mental health, particularly
for younger adults.

It's also one of these
things that's nuanced. What one person
thinks is hateful, another person might not.

What people need to see to do
their jobs might be surprising. We had a study recently, where
we were working with journalists

to say, how do we make social
media essentially usable for you when the majority of
messages you may receive

might be abusive? And every time you log
on to this platform, most of the messages you get
are these hateful messages.

And there are nuances to this. You need to know
as a journalist-- how are people reacting
to the stories you write?

How do you engage
with that community? How do you actually not want
to filter out all of this?

But maybe say, hey, if
these things are actually actionable threats, we don't
want to filter them out. I need them to
bubble to the top so

that I know for
my physical safety that these threats are
being made against me. We've looked at
platforms like Reddit

and tried to understand
what are the different ways harassment happens, which
I think, in many ways,

know this harassment happens. But again, it's
this deeply nuanced. There's different personas. There are different
types of harassment.

There's a big difference between
these one-off interactions, or a conversation gets
heated and becomes

abusive versus these trolls who
might go after and track people across different platforms,
or might bring together

a small army to go and
attack an individual. And the solutions
to those problems are going to be very different.

But we need to look at this
data and understand the nuance of the different
types of attacks, the different types of abusers,
to understand these nuances

on why some people think a
comment is abusive while others don't.

And there's a lot of
work to be done here. This is one of these interesting
areas that spans everything

from psychology in the
social sciences all the way to natural language processing.

How do you make sense of
these comments at scale and do these types
of measurements?

And I think there's a lot
of work to be done there. But it is one of these
areas that we really have to take both the
technical side of it,

but also really work
with our counterparts in other departments
and say, how do we make

sense of this complex issue? Because it's not this
black-and-white security where there's an attack, and we
simply need to filter it out.

It's going to have
much more complex, human-focused solutions. In many ways, it
may be something

that technology is
amplifying existing problems. And if we don't understand
those underlying human aspects

of this, we might end up doing
much more harm than we actually do in helping. The other part we've looked
at is these questions

around disinformation
and propaganda. And again, the part that my
group is really interested in is-- how do we track
how information

spreads on the internet? We are not ourselves
social science, and discerning whether or
not a story is true or false

is a really hard question. It's something
where you oftentimes need to have a deep
understanding of the politics

involved, of the players. It's something that
investigative journalists and other folks, we think,
are in a much better position

to make sense of. Oftentimes, stories
are-- there's some kernel of truth to
just sort of every story.

What we're interested
in, though, is asking questions
of saying, OK, where did this
story start online? Or is this something
that started out

of a Russian propaganda site? Is this something that
started on social media? Or is this something that
started for the first time

through a mainstream
media source? Can we track how that
information flows online?

And this is something
that-- what we want to do is enable social scientists
to be able to do research

about how the internet works. So how can we take our
large-scale systems? How can we take advances in
natural language processing?

And say, OK, if you want
to think about this topic. Here's where it's
been covered online. Here's where it started.

Here is the flow it
took online for you to then go and do
deeper social science
research on those topics. SPEAKER: Really interesting. So I mean, there's a lot there.

Again, it's just
building the tools in order to even collect the
data at scale that then you

maybe perform a more qualitative
or statistical analysis but informed by
your understanding

of human behavior,
human cognition, all those kinds of things. And just creating a taxonomy
of these broad categories

is itself an incredibly
complicated and fraught task. ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Yeah.

SPEAKER: That's
really interesting. So we're nearing
the end of our time. So what I would love to do maybe
is to talk a little bit more

you are able to enroll in that
class as a professional student if you meet the
prerequisites, which I think are a background in
Computer Science and Networking.

But you have all this research. You're talking about all these
kind of interesting nuances

to the way the internet
actually operates. So can you talk
a little bit more about what was the
inspiration for this class?

And maybe another
way to put it is-- what do you think is really
important for your average

computer science or
your average programmer to understand about the
internet that they might not from just a conventional
programming or computer science

background? ZAKIR DURUMERIC: Yeah. I think for me, what
it is we oftentimes focus on the
networking fundamentals

in the curriculum to start. And thinking about
the internet is a little bit different than
thinking about networking.

Networking is absolutely
a huge part of it. You do have the business piece. You have the governance piece.

You have these
misaligned incentives around how all of
this works and trying

to understand what
that looks like. What protocols
are actually used? Where does your traffic
actually go on the internet?

And I think the first
project is actually a great exemplar of this. The first project
in the class is

that you yourselves have to go
and actually join the internet. So we give you a router.

And we tell you who
your upstream ISP is. And you have to go
announce yourself to the internet
as a new network.

And what you get back
is every other network on the internet who's
announcing its presence.

And then from there,
we look at, well, who are the biggest networks? What are the differences?

Where does your
traffic go in ways that you just wouldn't expect? And why do you think
it's doing that?

Once you have this internet
connection, we set up honeypots. We look at-- what do attackers
do when you're on the internet? What is the actual
attack traffic

that you receive by just
being on the internet? We go and we actually
crawl websites

and say, OK, we keep
talking about how there's all these privacy
concerns about websites and third-party cookies and ads
and tracking and all of this.

But now that you have actually
the top-million websites in the internet, what ad
providers are on them?

Who are they? What amplifiers are showing
up on these health care sites? And so it's a much
more empirical class.

All of the projects
in the class are going out and measuring-- how
does the internet actually work? Not how do we want it to work.

Not how might it
theoretically work. But how does it actually work? And we build from the bottom up
at the routing and saying, OK,

you have the routing table
now for the full internet. Who are the players? And these players, you
realize you never even

heard of a lot of them. These biggest players who are
on the backbone of the internet are folks that are just
not household names,

and they're
critically important. But it's not something
you think about or talk about in Networking class.

We talk about governance. We talk about-- how much
does an IP address cost?

We're out. They're no longer free. So where do you go? You have to go join an
auction and put in a bid,

and get an IP address. What does that look like? And so a lot of it is saying,
how does the internet actually

work today? How do new standards happen? Where does your traffic go? What protocols are
actually in use.

But we want folks to
come out of the class and say, we actually have
a really good understanding now of like, when a computer is
on the internet, what happens?

Where does that go? When I actually connect
to Netflix, what happens?

Where are my packets going? Do they go over the core of
the internet, or they do not?

Why not? And those types of
questions, I think, really are important for
architecting future systems,

because you don't want
to architect systems based on how the internet might
used to work 20 or 30 years ago.

You want to architect
systems based on how the internet works today. What are the real
actual implications

of using a cloud provider or a
content distribution network? What traffic, if
you decide to use

Google Analytics on your site,
does Google have access to? When you decide to copy
and paste that JavaScript

into your file-- these are the types
of questions that we want folks to have a better
understanding of coming out

of the class. SPEAKER: I'm assuming,
it also gives them the ability, maybe in
10 years, to look again

and say, oh, it's changed again. ZAKIR DURUMERIC: It's changing. I know. This is one of the funny
things about this class, is we have to change it every
year because all of the numbers
change. New protocols come out. New things are deprecated. Companies rise and fall.

All of this is something
that's really quite dynamic. And it's fun to teach,
too, because you have people who do these
projects to come back and say,
who is this? And you realize, I don't know. I don't know who that is. I've never heard of them? They didn't exist last year?

But they're now a real
player in the space. SPEAKER: Zakir,
what would be-- we

had a great question from
one of the participants. Assuming unlimited

the resources you
have, what do you think is the next big research

What's the area of the internet
still a mystery to you? What are you interested in

I mean, it's hard to pick just
one because at each layer, there are so many of these
questions to make sense of.

I mean, the satellite piece, I
think, is really interesting. This is an entirely new dynamic.

We had cell networks, and
we had landline networks. But we haven't really had
satellite-based communication.

What does this
mean for protocols that we use for things like TCP? This is, I think, a
big open question.

The other piece that I'm
really of interested in still is understanding more
the real-world aspects

of how attacks happen
and what defenses really work to protect against them. So we've done a lot of this
empirical work about the network

and about the internet
and about protocols. A lot of my interest
today, too, is-- how do we start to collect the
same type of data about attacks?

How do we start to
make sense of what defenses are in there and not? Right now, we don't really
know what defenses really work.

We buy things based
on what we think, like groupthink says works. We don't have hard
data that says,

this is what it means
to get MFA right. And this is the place
you need to deploy it. And I'm really interested
in understanding

is-- how do we
take this approach and use it for
understanding that?
